channel.title: Nature
channel.description: Nature is the foremost international weekly scientific journal in the world and is the flagship journal for Nature Portfolio. It publishes the finest peer-reviewed research in all fields of science and technology on the basis of its originality, importance, interdisciplinary interest, timeliness, accessibility, elegance and surprising conclusions. Nature publishes landmark papers, award winning news, leading comment and expert opinion on important, topical scientific news and events that enable readers to share the latest discoveries in science and evolve the discussion amongst the global scientific community.
channel.dc:rights: © 2024 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.
channel.prism:copyright: © 2024 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.

item.title: Superconductivity case shows the need for zero tolerance of toxic lab culture
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00915-x

Superconductivity case shows the need for zero tolerance of toxic lab culture
item.dc:title: Superconductivity case shows the need for zero tolerance of toxic lab culture
item.dc:creator: Juan Pablo Fuenzalida Werner

item.title: Cuts to postgraduate funding threaten Brazilian science — again
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00916-w

Cuts to postgraduate funding threaten Brazilian science — again
item.dc:title: Cuts to postgraduate funding threaten Brazilian science — again
item.dc:creator: Marcus F. Oliveira
Adriane R. Todeschini

item.title: A glowing glass transmits X-rays with ease
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00862-7

Copper-containing ‘nanoclusters’ form glasses with an orderly structure and unusual properties.
item.dc:title: A glowing glass transmits X-rays with ease

item.title: The ‘Anthropocene’ is here to stay — and it’s better not as a geological epoch
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00914-y

The ‘Anthropocene’ is here to stay — and it’s better not as a geological epoch
item.dc:title: The ‘Anthropocene’ is here to stay — and it’s better not as a geological epoch
item.dc:creator: Thomas P. Roland
Graeme T. Swindles
Alastair Ruffell

item.title: Don’t underestimate the rising threat of groundwater to coastal cities
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00917-9

Don’t underestimate the rising threat of groundwater to coastal cities
item.dc:title: Don’t underestimate the rising threat of groundwater to coastal cities
item.dc:creator: Daniel J. Rozell

item.title: How a tree-hugging protest transformed Indian environmentalism
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00895-y

Fifty years ago, a group of women from the villages of the Western Himalayas sparked Chipko, a green movement that remains relevant in the age of climate change.
item.dc:title: How a tree-hugging protest transformed Indian environmentalism
item.dc:creator: Seema Mundoli

item.title: How AI is improving climate forecasts
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00780-8

Researchers are using various machine-learning strategies to speed up climate modelling, reduce its energy costs and hopefully improve accuracy.
item.dc:title: How AI is improving climate forecasts
item.dc:creator: Carissa Wong

item.title: A horse cemetery in London reveals medieval mounts’ distant origins
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00861-8

Horses buried near the royal complex of Westminster in the fifteenth and sixteenth centuries had been imported from as far away as Scandinavia.
item.dc:title: A horse cemetery in London reveals medieval mounts’ distant origins

item.title: I peer into volcanoes to see when they’ll blow
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00896-x

Mariton Antonia Bornas runs a Filipino volcano research and response organization.
item.dc:title: I peer into volcanoes to see when they’ll blow
item.dc:creator: Margaret Simons

item.title: How did the Big Bang get its name? Here’s the real story
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00894-z

Astronomer Fred Hoyle supposedly coined the catchy term to ridicule the theory of the Universe’s origins — 75 years on, it’s time to set the record straight.
item.dc:title: How did the Big Bang get its name? Here’s the real story
item.dc:creator: Helge Kragh

item.title: ‘Hopeless, burnt out, sad’: how political change is impacting female researchers in Latin America
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00885-0

Already feeling invisible and unappreciated, the election of far-right administrations in Argentina and elsewhere are unsettling for women in science.
item.dc:title: ‘Hopeless, burnt out, sad’: how political change is impacting female researchers in Latin America
item.dc:creator: Julie Gould

item.title: Larger or longer grants unlikely to push senior scientists towards high-risk, high-reward work
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00929-5

A survey of US professors suggests that broad changes to grant schemes might be needed to incentivize new approaches to research.
item.dc:title: Larger or longer grants unlikely to push senior scientists towards high-risk, high-reward work
item.dc:creator: Dalmeet Singh Chawla

item.title: Weird new electron behaviour in stacked graphene thrills physicists
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00832-z

This 2D material is only the second to exhibit the fractional quantum anomalous Hall effect, and theorists are still debating how it works.
item.dc:title: Weird new electron behaviour in stacked graphene thrills physicists
item.dc:creator: Dan Garisto

item.title: Publisher Correction: Visuo-frontal interactions during social learning in freely moving macaques
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07301-7

Publisher Correction: Visuo-frontal interactions during social learning in freely moving macaques
item.dc:title: Publisher Correction: Visuo-frontal interactions during social learning in freely moving macaques
item.dc:creator: Melissa Franch
Sudha Yellapantula
Arun Parajuli
Natasha Kharas
Anthony Wright
Behnaam Aazhang
Valentin Dragoi

item.title: ‘Best view ever’: observatory will map Big Bang’s afterglow in new detail
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00333-z

The Simons Observatory will search for signs of gravitational waves that originated from the Big Bang.
item.dc:title: ‘Best view ever’: observatory will map Big Bang’s afterglow in new detail
item.dc:creator: Davide Castelvecchi

item.title: Pregnancy advances your ‘biological’ age — but giving birth turns it back
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00843-w

Carrying a baby creates some of the same epigenetic patterns on DNA seen in older people.
item.dc:title: Pregnancy advances your ‘biological’ age — but giving birth turns it back
item.dc:creator: Saima Sidik

item.title: First pig kidney transplant in a person: what it means for the future
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00879-y

The early success of the operation has made researchers hopeful that clinical trials for xenotransplanted organs will start soon.
item.dc:title: First pig kidney transplant in a person: what it means for the future
item.dc:creator: Smriti Mallapaty
Max Kozlov

item.title: How to achieve safe water access for all: work with local communities
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00886-z

Four scientists reflect on how to foster a more sustainable relationship between water and society amid complex and wide-ranging challenges.
item.dc:title: How to achieve safe water access for all: work with local communities
item.dc:creator: Farhana Sultana
Tara McAllister
Suparana Katyaini
Michael D. Blackstock

item.title: Daily briefing: How PhD assessment needs to change
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00926-8

What Briefing readers think about how doctoral degrees should be evaluated. Plus, the X-factor in bird song that makes males irresistible and why like-charged particles can sometimes attract.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: How PhD assessment needs to change
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: A supercollider glimpses a gathering of three particles never seen together before
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00764-8

Data from billions of proton collisions reveal that subatomic particles called W+ and W− bosons keep company with a photon.
item.dc:title: A supercollider glimpses a gathering of three particles never seen together before

item.title: The future of at-home molecular testing
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00854-7

The COVID-19 pandemic showed what was possible for gene-based diagnostics. Now comes the true test – economics.
item.dc:title: The future of at-home molecular testing
item.dc:creator: Elie Dolgin

item.title: Google AI could soon use a person’s cough to diagnose disease
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00869-0

Machine-learning system trained on millions of human audio clips shows promise for detecting COVID-19 and tuberculosis.
item.dc:title: Google AI could soon use a person’s cough to diagnose disease
item.dc:creator: Mariana Lenharo

item.title: Daily briefing: COVID ‘brain fog’ linked to brain inflammation
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00881-4

Growing evidence suggests that the immune response triggered by SARS-CoV-2 is behind symptoms such as loss of smell, headaches and memory problems. Plus, a genetically modified pig liver has been transplanted into a person’s body for the first time.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: COVID ‘brain fog’ linked to brain inflammation
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: Cutting-edge CAR-T cancer therapy is now made in India — at one-tenth the cost
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00809-y

The treatment, called NexCAR19, raises hopes that this transformative class of medicine will become more readily available in low- and middle-income countries.
item.dc:title: Cutting-edge CAR-T cancer therapy is now made in India — at one-tenth the cost
item.dc:creator: Smriti Mallapaty

item.title: Squeeze, freeze, bake: how to make 3D-printed wood that mimics the real thing
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00767-5

Scientists turn waste wood into an ‘ink’ that can be printed into a variety of structures.
item.dc:title: Squeeze, freeze, bake: how to make 3D-printed wood that mimics the real thing

item.title: A view of wind turbines drives down home values — but only briefly
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00766-6

House prices drop by 1% if wind turbines are close and visible, but they rebound quickly.
item.dc:title: A view of wind turbines drives down home values — but only briefly

item.title: Structure and assembly of a bacterial gasdermin pore
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07216-3

Cryo-electron microscopy and molecular dynamics studies of a Vitiosangium gasdermin pore reveal insights into the assembly of this large and diverse family of membrane pore-forming proteins.
item.dc:title: Structure and assembly of a bacterial gasdermin pore
item.dc:creator: Alex G. Johnson
Megan L. Mayer
Stefan L. Schaefer
Nora K. McNamara-Bordewick
Gerhard Hummer
Philip J. Kranzusch

item.title: A host–microbiota interactome reveals extensive transkingdom connectivity
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07162-0

A new technology for proteome-scale assessment of human exoproteome–microbiome interactions exposes an extensive network of transkingdom connectivity.
item.dc:title: A host–microbiota interactome reveals extensive transkingdom connectivity
item.dc:creator: Nicole D. Sonnert

item.title: Rotating curved spacetime signatures from a giant quantum vortex
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07176-8

By stabilizing a stationary giant quantum vortex in superfluid 4He and introducing a minimally invasive way to characterize the vortex flow, intricate wave–vortex interactions are shown to simulate black hole ringdown physics.
item.dc:title: Rotating curved spacetime signatures from a giant quantum vortex
item.dc:creator: Patrik Švančara
Pietro Smaniotto
Leonardo Solidoro
James F. MacDonald
Sam Patrick
Ruth Gregory
Carlo F. Barenghi
Silke Weinfurtner

item.title: At least one in a dozen stars shows evidence of planetary ingestion
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07091-y

By analysing the chemical abundance differences of pairs of co-moving stars born together, it is found that about 8% show chemical signatures that indicate ingestion of planetary material.
item.dc:title: At least one in a dozen stars shows evidence of planetary ingestion
item.dc:creator: Fan Liu
Yuan-Sen Ting
David Yong
Bertram Bitsch
Amanda Karakas
Michael T. Murphy
Meridith Joyce
Aaron Dotter
Fei Dai

item.title: Dual quantum spin Hall insulator by density-tuned correlations in TaIrTe<sub>4</sub>
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07211-8

A study reports a dual quantum spin Hall insulator in monolayer TaIrTe4, arising from the interplay of its single-particle topology and density-tuned electron correlations.
item.dc:title: Dual quantum spin Hall insulator by density-tuned correlations in TaIrTe<sub>4</sub>

item.title: All-electrical skyrmionic magnetic tunnel junction
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07131-7

Wafer-scale realization of a nanoscale magnetic tunnel junction hosting a single, ambient skyrmion enables its large readout, efficient switching, and compatibility with lateral manipulation, and thereby provides the backbone for all-electrical skyrmionic device architectures.
item.dc:title: All-electrical skyrmionic magnetic tunnel junction

item.title: The hidden fitness of the male zebra finch courtship song
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07207-4

A detailed analysis of male song structure in zebra finches shows how females use particular features of songs as indicators of male quality in species that learn only one song.
item.dc:title: The hidden fitness of the male zebra finch courtship song
item.dc:creator: Danyal Alam
Fayha Zia
Todd F. Roberts

item.title: Evidence of the fractional quantum spin Hall effect in moiré MoTe<sub>2</sub>
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07214-5

Transport evidence of a fractional quantum spin Hall insulator is reported in 2.1°-twisted bilayer MoTe2, which supports spin-Sz conservation and flat spin-contrasting Chern bands.
item.dc:title: Evidence of the fractional quantum spin Hall effect in moiré MoTe<sub>2</sub>
item.dc:creator: Kaifei Kang
Bowen Shen
Yichen Qiu
Yihang Zeng
Zhengchao Xia
Kenji Watanabe
Takashi Taniguchi
Jie Shan
Kin Fai Mak

item.title: Venous-plexus-associated lymphoid hubs support meningeal humoral immunity
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07202-9

Dural-associated lymphoid tissues are lymphoid structures around vascular hubs in the dura mater that sample antigens and rapidly support humoral immune responses after local pathogen challenge.
item.dc:title: Venous-plexus-associated lymphoid hubs support meningeal humoral immunity
item.dc:creator: Zachary Fitzpatrick
Nagela Ghabdan Zanluqui

item.title: Resilient anatomy and local plasticity of naive and stress haematopoiesis
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07186-6

This study develops a method for spatially resolving multipotent haematopoiesis, erythropoiesis and lymphopoiesis in mice and uncovers heterogeneous haematopoietic stress responses in different bones.
item.dc:title: Resilient anatomy and local plasticity of naive and stress haematopoiesis
item.dc:creator: Qingqing Wu

item.title: Transcription–replication conflicts underlie sensitivity to PARP inhibitors
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07217-2

Poly(ADP-ribose) polymerase 1 (PARP1) functions together with TIMELESS and TIPIN to protect the replisome in early S phase from transcription–replication conflicts, and inhibiting PARP1 enzymatic activity may suffice for treatment efficacy in homologous recombination-deficient settings.
item.dc:title: Transcription–replication conflicts underlie sensitivity to PARP inhibitors
item.dc:creator: Michalis Petropoulos
Angeliki Karamichali
Giacomo G. Rossetti
Alena Freudenmann
Luca G. Iacovino
Vasilis S. Dionellis
Sotirios K. Sotiriou
Thanos D. Halazonetis

item.title: Proteome-scale discovery of protein degradation and stabilization effectors
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07224-3

A synthetic proteome-scale strategy enables the identification of a diverse range of human proteins that can induce the degradation or stabilization of a target protein in a proximity-dependent way.
item.dc:title: Proteome-scale discovery of protein degradation and stabilization effectors
item.dc:creator: Juline Poirson
Hanna Cho

item.title: Persistent interaction patterns across social media platforms and over time
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07229-y

Long conversations online consistently exhibit higher toxicity, yet toxic language does not invariably discourage people from participating in a conversation, and toxicity does not necessarily escalate as discussions evolve.
item.dc:title: Persistent interaction patterns across social media platforms and over time
item.dc:creator: Michele Avalle
Niccolò Di Marco

item.title: Cryo-EM structures of RAD51 assembled on nucleosomes containing a DSB site
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07196-4

Cryo-electron microscopy structures of human RAD51 in complex with the nucleosome show that RAD51 can adopt two conformations—rings and filaments—and reveal how RAD51 binds to the nucleosome through its N-terminal lobe domain.
item.dc:title: Cryo-EM structures of RAD51 assembled on nucleosomes containing a DSB site
item.dc:creator: Takuro Shioi
Suguru Hatazawa
Eriko Oya

Wataru Kobayashi
Mitsuo Ogasawara
Takehiko Kobayashi
Yoshimasa Takizawa
Hitoshi Kurumizaka

item.title: Non-reciprocal topological solitons in active metamaterials
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07097-6

A local driving mechanism for solitons that accelerates both solitons and antisolitons in the same direction, called non-reciprocal driving, is introduced, showing a subtle interplay between non-reciprocity and topological solitons and providing waveguiding and wave-processing possibilities for other fields.
item.dc:title: Non-reciprocal topological solitons in active metamaterials
item.dc:creator: Jonas Veenstra
Oleksandr Gamayun
Xiaofei Guo
Anahita Sarvi
Chris Ventura Meinersen
Corentin Coulais

item.title: Adaptive foraging behaviours in the Horn of Africa during Toba supereruption
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07208-3

The archaeological site Shinfa-Metema 1 in the lowlands of northwest Ethiopia provides early evidence of intensive riverine-based foraging aided by the likely adoption of the bow and arrow.
item.dc:title: Adaptive foraging behaviours in the Horn of Africa during Toba supereruption

item.title: A distinct Fusobacterium nucleatum clade dominates the colorectal cancer niche
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07182-w

A study reveals that Fusobacterium nucleatum subspecies animalis is bifurcated into two distinct clades, and shows that only one of these dominates the colorectal cancer niche, probably through increased colonization of the human gastrointestinal tract.
item.dc:title: A distinct Fusobacterium nucleatum clade dominates the colorectal cancer niche

item.title: Disease-associated astrocyte epigenetic memory promotes CNS pathology
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07187-5

In an experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis model in mice, a subset of astrocytes retains an epigenetically regulated memory of past inflammation, causing exacerbated inflammation upon subsequent rechallenge.
item.dc:title: Disease-associated astrocyte epigenetic memory promotes CNS pathology
item.dc:creator: Hong-Gyun Lee

item.title: Motor neurons generate pose-targeted movements via proprioceptive sculpting
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07222-5

Single motor neurons in Drosophila are stimulated to show that they direct head movements towards specific postures rather than generating fixed movement vectors, suggesting that the brain controls movements through a continuing proprioceptive–motor loop.
item.dc:title: Motor neurons generate pose-targeted movements via proprioceptive sculpting

item.title: Compensatory evolution in NusG improves fitness of drug-resistant M. tuberculosis
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07206-5

In Mycobacterium tuberculosis, the fitness cost of rifampicin resistance is partially due to excessive RNA polymerase pausing and is rescued by mutations in the pro-pausing transcription factor NusG.
item.dc:title: Compensatory evolution in NusG improves fitness of drug-resistant M. tuberculosis
item.dc:creator: Kathryn A. Eckartt
Madeleine Delbeau

item.title: Global prediction of extreme floods in ungauged watersheds
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07145-1

Artificial intelligence-based forecasting improves the reliability of predicting extreme flood events in ungauged watersheds, with predictions at five days lead time that are as good as current systems are for same-day predictions.
item.dc:title: Global prediction of extreme floods in ungauged watersheds
item.dc:creator: Grey Nearing
Deborah Cohen
Vusumuzi Dube

Yossi Matias

item.title: Benchmarking highly entangled states on a 60-atom analogue quantum simulator
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07173-x

Fidelity benchmarking of an analogue quantum simulator reaches a high-entanglement regime where exact classical simulation of quantum systems becomes impractical, and enables a new method for evaluating the mixed-state entanglement of quantum devices.
item.dc:title: Benchmarking highly entangled states on a 60-atom analogue quantum simulator
item.dc:creator: Adam L. Shaw
Zhuo Chen
Joonhee Choi
Daniel K. Mark
Pascal Scholl
Ran Finkelstein
Andreas Elben
Soonwon Choi
Manuel Endres

item.title: Pattern formation by turbulent cascades
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07074-z

Turbulent energy cascades can be arrested by non-dissipative viscosities, resulting in pattern formation at intermediate length scales.
item.dc:title: Pattern formation by turbulent cascades
item.dc:creator: Xander M. de Wit
Michel Fruchart
Tali Khain
Federico Toschi
Vincenzo Vitelli

item.title: Role of IL-27 in Epstein–Barr virus infection revealed by IL-27RA deficiency
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07213-6

IL-27RA–IL-27 has a critical role in the immunity to EBV, and this defence is hijacked by Epstein–Barr virus to promote the expansion of infected transformed B cells
item.dc:title: Role of IL-27 in Epstein–Barr virus infection revealed by IL-27RA deficiency

item.title: Magnetic whirlpools offer improved data storage
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00576-w

Complex magnetic structures called skyrmions have been generated on a nanometre scale and controlled electrically — a promising step for fast, energy-efficient computer hardware systems that can store large amounts of data.
item.dc:title: Magnetic whirlpools offer improved data storage
item.dc:creator: Qiming Shao

item.title: One year, three researchers, millions of cells: how a small team created the largest mouse-embryo atlas so far
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00870-7

A map of mouse development from conception to birth tracks 12.4 million cells at single-cell resolution as they mature into organs and other tissues.
item.dc:title: One year, three researchers, millions of cells: how a small team created the largest mouse-embryo atlas so far
item.dc:creator: Sara Reardon

item.title: COVID’s toll on the brain: new clues emerge
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00828-9

A leaky blood–brain barrier and inflammation might account for some of the cognitive symptoms of COVID-19.
item.dc:title: COVID’s toll on the brain: new clues emerge
item.dc:creator: Claudia López Lloreda

item.title: Planet-eating stars hint at hidden chaos in the Milky Way
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00847-6

A handful of middle-aged stars seem to have gobbled up a planet, challenging assumptions about the stability of such systems.
item.dc:title: Planet-eating stars hint at hidden chaos in the Milky Way
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Gibney

item.title: The warfighter
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00821-2

Welcome home.
item.dc:title: The warfighter
item.dc:creator: Timothy Quinn

item.title: Daily briefing: Abel Prize for randomness mathematician Michel Talagrand
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00873-4

Michel Talagrand has won one of mathematics’ biggest prizes for his work developing formulae to make random processes more predictable. Plus, climate models can’t explain 2023’s huge heat anomaly and NASA ponders the enormous cost of bringing Mars rocks back to Earth.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Abel Prize for randomness mathematician Michel Talagrand
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: ‘Woah, this is affecting me’: why I’m fighting racial inequality in prostate-cancer research
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00857-4

Olugbenga Samuel Oyeniyi sought a career with a stronger public-health focus after learning that Black men are twice as likely as white men to get prostate cancer.
item.dc:title: ‘Woah, this is affecting me’: why I’m fighting racial inequality in prostate-cancer research
item.dc:creator: Jacqui Thornton

item.title: AI hears hidden X factor in zebra finch love songs
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00864-5

Machine learning detects song differences too subtle for humans to hear, and physicists harness the computing power of the strange skyrmion.
item.dc:title: AI hears hidden X factor in zebra finch love songs
item.dc:creator: Nick Petrić Howe
Benjamin Thompson

item.title: These ‘movies’ of proteins in action are revealing the hidden biology of cells
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00817-y

A burgeoning technique called time-resolved cryo-EM is granting insights into the tiny motors and devices that power life.
item.dc:title: These ‘movies’ of proteins in action are revealing the hidden biology of cells
item.dc:creator: Ewen Callaway

item.title: Ketamine is in the spotlight thanks to Elon Musk — but is it the right treatment for depression?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00852-9

The entrepreneur endorses the drug, but researchers caution that it’s not to be taken lightly.
item.dc:title: Ketamine is in the spotlight thanks to Elon Musk — but is it the right treatment for depression?
item.dc:creator: David Adam

item.title: Are we in the Anthropocene yet?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00815-0

Measurement matters, but should not detract from the reality that humans are altering Earth systems.
item.dc:title: Are we in the Anthropocene yet?

item.title: Astrocyte cells in the brain have immune memory
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00676-7

The central nervous system’s astrocyte cells respond to injury and disease. The finding that they form molecular memories of certain responses, and that these modify inflammatory signalling, sheds light on autommunity.
item.dc:title: Astrocyte cells in the brain have immune memory
item.dc:creator: Michael V. Sofroniew

item.title: Neuron migration to brain regions key to memory and navigation continues into childhood
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00054-3

This study identifies a major migratory route for young neurons in the brains of young children. This route forms during pregnancy and links the birthplace of these nerve cells to their destination in highly interconnected brain regions that are responsible for memory and spatial processing.
item.dc:title: Neuron migration to brain regions key to memory and navigation continues into childhood

item.title: Powerful microscopy reveals blood-cell production in bone marrow
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00504-y

A method for imaging the production of blood cells in the bones of mice has revealed the organization of cell lineages, both in a steady state and in response to stressors, such as bleeding and infection.
item.dc:title: Powerful microscopy reveals blood-cell production in bone marrow
item.dc:creator: M. Carolina Florian

item.title: Mathematician who tamed randomness wins Abel Prize
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00839-6

Michel Talagrand laid mathematical groundwork that has allowed others to tackle problems involving random processes.
item.dc:title: Mathematician who tamed randomness wins Abel Prize
item.dc:creator: Davide Castelvecchi

item.title: Whittling down the bacterial subspecies that might drive colon cancer
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00662-z

Understanding the factors that drive formation of particular types of cancer can aid efforts to develop better diagnostics or treatments. The identification of a bacterial subspecies with a connection to colon cancer has clinical relevance.
item.dc:title: Whittling down the bacterial subspecies that might drive colon cancer
item.dc:creator: Cynthia L. Sears
Jessica Queen

item.title: Is AI ready to mass-produce lay summaries of research articles?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00865-4

A surge in tools that generate text is allowing research papers to be summarized for a broad audience, and in any language. But scientists caution that major challenges remain.
item.dc:title: Is AI ready to mass-produce lay summaries of research articles?
item.dc:creator: Kamal Nahas

item.title: Complex motions emerge from robot interactions
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00622-7

An array of robots has been set up so that pushes between them produce movements that do not conform to the usual laws of motion. Fascinating behaviour emerges from these interactions: wave phenomena known as solitons.
item.dc:title: Complex motions emerge from robot interactions
item.dc:creator: Sebastian D. Huber
Kukka-Emilia Huhtinen

item.title: First pig liver transplanted into a person lasts for 10 days
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00853-8

Pig organs could provide temporary detox for people whose livers need time to recover or who are awaiting human donors.
item.dc:title: First pig liver transplanted into a person lasts for 10 days
item.dc:creator: Smriti Mallapaty

item.title: It’s final: the Anthropocene is not an epoch, despite protest over vote
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00868-1

Governing body upholds earlier decision by geoscientists amid drama.
item.dc:title: It’s final: the Anthropocene is not an epoch, despite protest over vote
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Witze

item.title: China’s medical-device industry gets a makeover
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00823-0

The country is keen to boost its production of medical technology to reduce its reliance on imports. Analysts discuss the impact of policies.
item.dc:title: China’s medical-device industry gets a makeover
item.dc:creator: Sandy Ong

item.title: Birds convey complex signals in simple songs
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00677-6

The quality of a bird’s song during courtship can influence whether a male is selected as a mate. An innovative approach using machine learning offers a way to analyse the characteristics of birdsong.
item.dc:title: Birds convey complex signals in simple songs
item.dc:creator: Kate T. Snyder
Nicole Creanza

item.title: What Putin’s next term means for science
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00863-6

Researchers in Russia expect growing isolation as Vladimir Putin embarks on six more years as president.
item.dc:title: What Putin’s next term means for science
item.dc:creator: Olga Dobrovidova

item.title: Long-term continuous ammonia electrosynthesis
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07276-5

Long-term continuous ammonia electrosynthesis
item.dc:title: Long-term continuous ammonia electrosynthesis

item.title: Language and cultural norms influence vaccine hesitancy
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00826-x

Language and cultural norms influence vaccine hesitancy
item.dc:title: Language and cultural norms influence vaccine hesitancy
item.dc:creator: Mian Jia
